I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed project will be the second Asian Development Bank (ADB) loan to Energy 
Efficiency Services Limited (EESL) of India to support expansion of energy saving investments, 
following the Demand-Side Energy Efficiency Sector Project, approved in 2016.1 The project will 
follow new business models tested and improved to exploit vast opportunities in energy-efficiency 
investments. Interventions will include investments in distributed renewable energy closer to the 
consumer-end in rural agricultural areas, smart meters, and electric vehicles (e-vehicles) and 
charging stations in various states of India.  
 
2.  The project is aligned with the following impact: emissions intensity of economy reduced.2 
The project will have the following outcome: electricity end-use efficiency in the project areas 
increased. The project will have two outputs: Output 1: Energy-efficient technologies promoted and 
deployed in eligible states; and Output 2: End-user energy-efficiency awareness and capacity 
increased. ADB will provide a sovereign guaranteed loan of $250 million from its ordinary capital 
resources. The Clean Technology Fund will provide loan cofinancing of $46 million equivalent, to 
be  administered  by  ADB.  EESL  is  proceeding  with  advance  procurement  actions  for 
three subprojects under output 1. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will support EESL in implementing the proposed 
project. The TA will provide support for (i) project management consultants (primarily monitoring 
and reporting), (ii) key elements of the gender action plan, (iii) identification and development of 
remaining subprojects, and (iv) mapping of candidate sites for vehicle charging systems. The TA 
will support EESL in project management, technology and business model analyses, workshops 
and seminars, and selective pilot-testing of new and promising technologies or business models 
that can be rapidly deployed at scale through the project. The activities to be supported by the TA 
are noncommercial, i.e., they do not generate revenue for EESL, and are additional to EESL’s 
day-to-day operations. The TA is not listed in ADB’s current country operations business plan for 
India.3    
 
4.  The proposed project complements other ADB energy sector investments, almost all of 
which are on the supply-side in electricity generation, transmission, and distribution. This will be 
one of the few projects specifically focusing on demand-side energy efficiency and business 
models, which can be further scaled up in India and other ADB developing member countries. 
EESL continues to investigate opportunities to expand its services and is able to create new 
market opportunities through large-scale deployment of new technologies using new business 
models such as leasing of e-vehicles to remove up-front cost barriers to vehicle users. The 
investments in distributed solar utilize proven technologies combined with a  relatively new 
business model in clean energy services. The TA will support continued investigation of new 
opportunities that can be rapidly scaled-up in the country through the project. 
 
 
1   ADB. India: Demand-Side Energy Efficiency Sector Project. https://www.adb.org/projects/48224-002/main  
2 Government  of  India,  Ministry  of  Environment,  Forest  and  Climate  Change.  2015.  India’s  Intended 
NationallyDetermined Contribution: Working Towards Climate Justice. New Delhi.   
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 December 2018.

2 
5.  The traditional business model of energy service companies (ESCOs) has worked to a 
limited extent but continues to evolve: EESL is expanding its market scope to include upstream 
efficiency opportunities that have not been targeted by traditional ESCO investments. New 
business models are being tested and improved to address more expansive opportunities, 
including e-mobility and distributed renewable energy in the “last mile” of on-grid supply to rural 
agricultural areas.4 Additional opportunities exist in energy supply chains and other infrastructure 
services characterized by significant consumption of energy or other resources, e.g., value-added 
agricultural processing, water supply, and wastewater treatment.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  Output  1:  New  energy-efficiency  business  opportunities  identified.  The  TA  will 
facilitate the organic growth of EESL through expansion of its activities with existing clients and 
identification of opportunities to gain new clients, including potential deployment of advanced 
technologies for identified and/or future subprojects under the  proposed project. Expanded 
services will build on existing programs of lighting, pumping, buildings, smart metering, distributed 
on-grid renewable energy, and e-mobility. EESL routinely conducts pilot tests as part of its 
business development operations. Under the TA project, EESL will pilot-test new technologies 
and business models. Pilot tests will be considered in cases where there is demand from existing 
and potential new clients of EESL, identified sites for installation and operation, and where a 
successful prototype operation can be scaled up in an ensuing project or subproject under 
ongoing ADB-funded investment operations. Pilot tests should not result in any potential adverse 
environmental and/or social impacts, and should be Category C for environment, involuntary 
resettlement, and indigenous people.  
 
7.  Output 2: Project management improved and streamlined. The TA will support EESL 
in implementing the project (para. 3) and streamlining business operations, primarily through 
digitization and automation of internal processes. Key activities to be supported are:  
 
(i)  Monitoring,  reporting,  and  verifying  energy  savings  to  meet  ADB  project 
implementation  requirements  and  reporting  requirements  under  the  Clean 
Technology Fund results framework;  
(ii)  Financial management and procurement following ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time);  
(iii)  Implementation of the gender action plan for the project including documenting and 
implementing  best  practices  for effective  gender  mainstreaming  in  energy-
efficiency investments and internally within EESL; and 
(iv)  Streamlining  subprojects  identification,  selection,  design,  appraisal,  and 
implementation. 
 
8.  These activities will be linked to activities under output 1 of the proposed project. ADB will 
also support EESL’s participation in knowledge-sharing platforms such as the Asia Clean Energy 
Forum and similar events in the region, with emphasis on learning-by-doing. Social media and 
websites will be the primary mode of knowledge sharing. Reports, best practice guidance, 
workshop proceedings, and other knowledge products will be published on a periodic basis on 
ADB’s website and social media and through conferences such as the Asia Clean Energy Forum. 
 
4  For example, e-mobility comprising a shared and connected vehicle fleet by 2030 will cut energy demand by 64% 
and carbon emissions by 37%; the benefits in public health and energy security cannot be overstated. Installation of 
renewable energy at distribution substations will alleviate overloading and technical losses in the low-voltage 
networks and reduce the need for more centralized generation plants.

3 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $2.1 million, of which $2.0 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Clean Technology Fund (CTF). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
10.  The  CTF  grant  will  finance  expenditures  for:  (i)  consultants’  services;  (ii)  training, 
workshops, and seminars; and (iii) pilot projects of new technologies and business models. The 
following expenditures are ineligible for CTF grant funding: salaries for civil servants in recipient 
countries, purchase of vehicles, and salaries and travel of ADB staff and consultants unless they 
are resource persons. 
 
11.  The  EESL  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office 
accommodation, and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of 
the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s South Asia Energy Division will select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants; assist in procuring goods as necessary; organize workshops; and lead in 
development of knowledge products in close coordination with EESL.

14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.5 The TA will require a firm that will be recruited following quality- and 
cost-based selection using 90:10 criteria. The scope of services to be provided does not involve 
complex  or  unusual  activities;  therefore,  simplified  technical  proposals  is  appropriate  for 
recruitment of the consulting firm. Individual consultants will be recruited for other activities. A 
total of 25 person-months of international experts and 108 person-months of national experts will 
be required. The consultants will have expertise in (i) project monitoring and reporting, as required 
by ADB and CTF; (ii) ADB procurement processes; (iii) energy-efficiency project identification, 
selection, appraisal, design, and implementation; (iv) automation and digitization of business 
processes; (v) preliminary financial and economic analyses of candidate investments following 
ADB guidelines; (vi) project structuring for rapid deployment and private sector participation; (vii) 
assessment of new technologies and business models for expanded energy-efficiency services, 
including pilot-testing and scale-up; (viii) social and environment safeguards; and effective gender 
mainstreaming. The required consulting services are summarized in Table 2.

15.  Cofinancier requirements. CTF monitoring and reporting requirements are consistent 
with the proposed project’s design and monitoring framework. 
 
E.  Governance 
 
16.  Due diligence of EESL for the proposed main project has included a financial management 
assessment, a procurement capacity assessment, and integrity due diligence. No outstanding 
issues have been identified.
